segments.text: Dr. Thomas, would you tell us about some of the ways that you have gone about raising money for research endeavors?
Well, now you're talking just generally about raising money for research, or are you talking about specifically for the center here?
For the center here.
For the center.
Okay.
Well, the...
The main objective when you have a new organization such as this is and has been, you have to establish your credibility.
And you have to get your name before those who sponsor work.
And we were very fortunate in having early on a relationship with Professor John Erickson of the University of Edinburgh
in Scotland, who is a, well, John is probably one of the Western world's foremost experts in the Soviet Union and Soviet military history.
And, well, he is a Kremlinologist, as some of them are called.
And so we were lucky in hooking up with him very early.
John's fame in the U.S. and around the world brought us some degree of notoriety rather early on.
In essence, we rode John's coattails into this new arena that Texas A&M had decided to try to enter.
And then, in addition to that, it was a question of trying to identify problems that were
of national or international interest and addressing those problems and showing people that, in fact, we could do work of this type.
I think we've had some success in that.
Of course, you have to understand that there is a certain amount of huckstering to this whole business.

One of the problems that you have with a young professor, you say a young assistant professor who has just gotten his PhD, and he comes to Texas A&M, and he realizes that in order to get ahead here, why, you've got to learn to bring in money.
What he doesn't realize is that the business of bringing money does not depend strictly on one's technical ability.

A lot of these young fellows think that in order to get money that all they have to do is to write out a proposal, a technically excellent proposal, and send it off to the National Science Foundation or NASA or DOD and say send money by return mail.
Well, it just doesn't happen that way.
You have to sell yourself.
You have to convince the sponsor that you're capable of doing good work and that you will
that you'll do some good for him.
Chances are he's a bureaucrat.
He functions in that mode.
He is judged by his effectiveness and by the impact of the money that he dispenses to others.
Obviously, if a guy sits up there and gives money to people who don't perform, he's not going to have money to give to them very long.
So the business of raising research is a combination of competence and marketing and huckstering and so forth.
And some academicians recoil at that.
They think, well, it just ought to be Simon Pure.
And you ought to be judged strictly on your merits, your technical merits.
And I suppose that would be nice if that's the way it was.
But unfortunately, that's not the way it is.

So we, the past two years then, I have spent an awful lot of time in Washington and other places, and just telling people about the Center, telling them about Texas A&M, because, you know, this Texas A&M has been, down over the years, a kind of a parochial university.
It, of course, being a land-grant school, why it
it felt responsive to the needs of the state.
And so as a result, it has not been nationally involved for many years.
And so the center here sort of represents one of Texas A&M's efforts to become nationally involved and internationally involved.
But there was just an awful lot of people that had seen Texas A&M's football team on the field and had seen the Corps of Cadets and didn't really understand that, you know.
I should say the marching band and the military aspects of the university.
But just surprising how many of those folks needed to understand what Texas A&M was and what it was like and the fact that it is not just another
pretty university.
And so there's been a lot of that, and essentially just the business of establishing credibility and so forth.
But it has, oh, I'm pleased with what we've accomplished to date, and I guess we'll get into that later, but we've still got quite a ways to go.
What are some of the sources of funding that the research department has brought here?
Well, the bulk of the funding from outside, well, I guess we need to back up now a little bit.
And you need to understand the way the center has been structured for most of its existence.
That is where we have had a series of groups within the center.
Until prior to the first of June of this year, we had the Industrial Economics Group.
It draws its funding largely from cities and other entities around over the state of Texas.
So the city of Del Rio, for example, or let's see, I guess actually it was the COG, the Council of Governments around Del Rio,
hired the industrial economics group back a year ago to do an industrial base study.
And that means they go in there and they try to delineate all of the elements of the economic base for that region of the state.
And of course, they were wondering what they could do to broaden that.
And they were wondering specifically about how important an element of tourism was and how to beef that up.
And so our people went in there and made the appropriate surveys and recommendations and presented that to the folks down there.
So that funding came from the four or five county region around Del Rio.
And they've done similar things for the city of Orange and the city of Big Spring and so forth.
And if you interview John Roberts, who now heads the revised industrial economics division,
a separate entity now, why he can tell you more about that.
Then we have an urban group, which essentially tries to help city administrations around over the state, trying to increase the efficiency of the delivery of city government services to the citizens.
Some of their funding comes from the cities.
Some of it came from the National Science Foundation,
which provided funding to set up something called the Texas Innovation Group, which is a group of around 40 cities that work together.
Then we had this education group, and the bulk of their funding, their work deals largely with the CETA program.
And so they have what we call pass-through money.
It's federal money that comes from the, I guess, from the Office of Education, Department of Education,
and comes to the governor, and then from the governor to us.

And then we have a special studies group, and they were involved in hurricane response modeling, trying to, among other things, figure out how to evacuate Galveston Island in the teeth of a large hurricane.
Now that money came partly from the state and partly from NOAA.
the National Office of Atmospheric and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
I'll get it right here shortly.
And also we have a man here who is an expert in some of these exotic crops like Wai'uli and jojoba.
Waiuli is a little shrub that grows wild in the Mexican desert and secretes latex.
Can you spell that?
G-U-Y-U-L-E, Waiuli.
And we have a man here, Dan Bragg, who probably knows more about the economics of Waiuli than anybody else in the world.
And there are those who think that
that we need to make way more of a cash crop in the U.S.
The Mexicans cultivated.
They have a processing plant at Sotillo in Mexico.
Can you spell that?
Sotillo, S-A-L-T-I-L-L-O.
And that money for Dan's work had come from the National Science Foundation.
And, let's see, then in the defense group, which of course is the
sort of really the main reason that the center exists.
The bulk of that money comes from DOD.
I should say not the bulk of it, all of it comes from DOD currently.
And a large part of it from the Office of Net Assessments, which is part of the Office of Secretary of Defense.
And then we now have a program that is being funded by the Defense Intelligence Agency.
That's DIA, not CIA.

And we've also done some work for the Foreign Technology Division at Wright-Patterson, which is the descendant of the old organization that I worked for up there, the Air Technical Intelligence Center.
You mentioned earlier that some of the research work that the center does is unclassified because of the military sensiveness of the- It's classified because of the- Excuse me, classified.
I have the wrong word.
Is any of this information, can it be obtained through the Freedom of Information Act?
I don't know enough about the legal ramifications of it.
I would guess not.
I know that there's a controversy underway in Congress now that a bill has been introduced to exempt the CIA from this Freedom of Information Act.
Yes, uh-huh.
Do you have any ideas on that?
Yeah, I'm afraid I'll reveal some biases here.
Of course, you know in the wake of Watergate and so forth, there was a
some dismantling of our intelligence operations, a move that I think has gone far too far.
And there was established this Freedom of Information Act which guaranteed access to certain classified or guarded material.
And, of course, it established several oversight committees in Congress to look over the shoulder of CIA.

That, by and large, has been a disaster because congressmen being the political animals, and senators, I don't mean just representatives, but being the political animals they are, they just can't keep their mouths shut.

And we have, I think we have severely damaged the position and stature of the United States by dismantling essential parts of our intelligence apparatus and by permitting people to leak secret material.
And it's been a sad
operation.
Now then, I would have to say that there very likely were excesses, abuses of that power that the CIA had and that the so-called imperial presidency had, but I worry less about that, frankly.
I think I would rather see
perhaps some modest abuse of power in contrast to a completely open situation.
I just don't agree that the press has a right to know everything.
And I think, you know, the pendulum swings and we'll find the correct position here eventually, but we're not there yet.
Let me ask you, do you know
in numbers about how many other universities have similar centers for strategic technology that Texas A&M has?
Or is this a rare phenomenon, relatively rare?
Well, it all depends on how rigidly or broadly you define the word similar.
There are outfits that do Soviet Warsaw Pact research work.
At Harvard there is an outfit called the Russian Research Center.
Probably one of the better known organizations is the Hoover Institution, which is affiliated with Stanford University.
The Mershon Center at Ohio State.
Mershon, M-E-R-S-H-O-N Center at Ohio State is pretty well known.
Center for Strategic Studies at Georgetown University in Washington is very well known.
And there is a Center for International Studies, I guess they call it, in Florida.
I think it's at the University of Florida at Gainesville, I believe, but I'm not sure about that.
And so, yes, there are similar kinds of organizations that is similar in terms of the type of work that they do.
Now, our philosophy, our operational philosophy, however, is rather different than those.
So this is where I get in the business of being a little bit more specific about the word similar.
One of the reasons that the Center exists
is that we had been encouraged by some fairly high-ranking military officers to get into this game.

And what they were telling us was that some of the existing think tanks, and there are those who refer to us as the Aggie think tank, and I guess that's to some extent true, but some of the existing, that most of the existing think tanks had
had gotten caught up in the Washington scene.
There are two large ones which are not affiliated with universities, the RAND Corporation, R-A-N-D, and of course, the Brookings Institute in Washington.
They've been in this business a long time, as well as these other university things.
But what we were told was that they have been in the business so long, and they have become so much a part of the Washington scene
that they'd begun to feed on one another.
And I know from my experience when I was at the University of Maryland and being in the Washington area that these people all attend the same cocktail parties.
They attend the same briefings.
And, well, as a result, there's just no fresh thinking that comes out of them.
And so this was one of the things that we were told very clearly, that the nation needed a new boy on the block.
to do some fresh thinking, and somebody that was not a part of the Washington scene.
And we sure as the deuce qualify on that basis.

Beyond that, one very high-ranking military officer told me, he said, you know, Dick, he said, he said our track record in terms of predicting and evaluating Soviet actions and intentions has not been good.
And

And one of the main reasons for that is the so-called mirror image syndrome, which is a view that the Soviet Union sees the world the way we do, a view that believes that they respond to pressures the way we would, that they want the same things in the world that we do, and that's just flat wrong.
They think differently.
They act differently.
They believe differently.
And a lot of our erroneous assessments of the USSR has derived from that mirror image syndrome.
And I had had a brush with that when I was at ATIC way back before I went back to do my graduate
I can tell you more about that.
It involves some classified stuff, but I can give you an unclassified description of it.
But from the beginning then, my view has been that we were not going to fall into that trap.
That we were, to the extent that we could, we were going to learn how to think Soviet.
In other words, when an issue or a problem came up, we're going to try to
try to think about it the way the Soviets would.
And this is a rather different viewpoint than any of these other institutions have.
Yeah, I notice you have a Soviet map on the wall behind you here, so that's to give you that perspective.
That's right.
That's right.
And Professor Erickson at the University of Edinburgh, who I mentioned earlier, has been very important in this because

course John you know he's a brilliant man speaks six languages including Russian fluently travels in Russia extensively and his view is that it doesn't make any difference whether you're talking about Afghanistan or you're talking about space warfare or you're talking about Poland or or what that the in order to understand
the way the Russians operate, you have to understand the Soviet psyche.
And I regret to say we have not spent a lot of time doing that.

We spent a lot of money studying the accuracy of their missiles, and we can tell you how accurate they are, and we can tell you how fast their airplanes fly, and we can tell you how thick the armament is on their, the armor plating is on their tanks, and so forth.
But when you come to study the Soviet military man, the guy who
pulls the trigger or pushes the button or gives the order or the people that back him up, we really don't understand a great deal about the Soviet Union.
And so that's one of the underlying philosophies that we have here, that we're going to make our studies, every one that we do, just as broad as we possibly can.
And so one of the messages that I carried to people who would sponsor our work was that philosophy.
And I had to tell them, if you give us money to study, say, Soviet moves toward space warfare capability, we're not going to limit it just to the technological studies.
We're going to try to understand the people that make the decisions
that undergird that whole effort?
And where are the research institutes that supply that technology?
How do Brezhnev and the Politburo feel about that?
What sort of policy views do they have?
What are the decision-making processes that underlie all of that?
And so we tackle things rather broadly here.

uh then there was another another element to this thing too i mentioned to you that that there were some high-ranking people and and also i i've talked about the military but but we had well i have a former student who's on the staff of the senate armed services committee he's an a m graduate and of course he uh he works now for senator tower and and uh
And he has some very strong views, and he's in a unique position to observe a lot of this stuff.
And from him and from others, even military people, they admitted that they had been part of the problem here.
That is to say that in the past, an outfit
would come to the military in Washington to get money to do a piece of research work.
And this, more often than not, was not a university outfit.
It would be typically one of what we call the Beltway Bandits, which is the array of little organizations, R&D organizations, that dot the Beltway around.
What was that word?
Beltway Bandits, they called them.
And they're outfits who sell their services to the Pentagon and to other agencies in Washington.

Well, if one of these outfits came to the Pentagon and got a chunk of money, in the process of negotiating the contract and talking about the work, the Pentagon, the military officers would tell the outfit, in essence, what they thought the answer would be when they
completed this research.
More often than not, lo and behold, that was in fact the answer that showed up.
And I don't know that there was anything necessarily malicious about this.
It was just something that happened.
And so there was a crying need for objectivity in a lot of these studies.
and a crying need for an organization that would simply call a spade a spade.
And if you came up with an answer that was somewhat different than what the sponsor thought it was going to be, well, that's the way it was.
In short, it was hoped that we could avoid a position where we might be judged to be intellectual prostitutes, more or less.
So there was one other element to this thing that I might mention that deals with your comment about classified material.
I know when I was in this game first, way back years ago, there was an awful lot of open literature stuff that is unclassified material that came across my desk.
But being young and impressionable,
Of course, I saw top secret stuff, too, and stuff that was classified beyond that.
And I thought that the top secret stuff was a hell of a lot more valuable than the open stuff.
The open literature just wasn't worth anything because it was open.
Well, that's wrong.
That's an erroneous view.
And of course, the Russians now publish and disseminate an awful lot of literature about themselves.

and so one of the things that again this was to some extent the Erickson influence on us Erickson works only with open literature and and he knows an awful lot about what is going on in Russia and he understands of course an awful lot about the Soviets and so
Another of our operational philosophies here is that we will mine the open literature assiduously.
And yeah, we'll do classified work, but we don't necessarily think that the answers are all in classified documents.
And so we do, the bulk of our work to date has been unclassified open literature searches.
Could you touch briefly on
Maybe some study that's being undergone now or has recently been completed.
Yeah, we can give you two or three examples.
That'd be sufficient, thank you.
Okay.
First of all, the Pentagon has asked us here to, this was an offshoot of the Erickson program,
set up a so-called program of excellence for the study of Soviet military organizations and personnel.
And the first study that was undertaken in that program was a study of Soviet military districts.
The Soviet Union is divided up into about 16 military districts.
They are unique.
organizational entities.
There's nothing else like it anyplace else in the world.
Well, I take that back.
I guess the Chinese have military districts, but they are relatively recent developments.
However, the military districts in the Soviet Union existed back in czarist times.
They represent an effort on the part of the Soviet military to bring the military right down to grassroots control and grassroots involvement throughout the USSR.
We don't really understand how they function, especially in wartime.

and you have to understand that the invasion of afghanistan was not done by the soviet army it was done by the two adjoining military districts the turkestan military district and the central asian military district and so they now i don't mean to infer that they are autonomous in some areas they are you see military training in the soviet union starts in the second grade
And the local military districts have the responsibility for that training program for Soviet school children.
In that sort of a function, they are relatively autonomous.
But I surely don't mean to infer that the two commanders of the military districts got together and said, hey, let's invade Afghanistan.
No, that's not yet.
They are linked directly to the Ministry of Defense in Moscow, and the Ministry of Defense calls the shots.
But an awful lot of the logistics and the rear services and supply and a fair amount of the troop supply come from the military districts.
So it's a kind of a unique and odd organizational entity.
And so our study here was to try to understand how those military districts function

uh what they uh what they do what they don't do how much how much autonomy do they have and they are disparate in their in their organizational structure some of them are quite complex others are fairly simple some of them will have civil defense responsibilities some of them do not so it's kind of an odd odd quirk so we are just now
in the final stages of actually what will turn out to be a first part of a two-stage study of Soviet military districts.
We had thought initially it would just be one element, which would be largely historical.
However, the second element, which we will do next year, will deal with what we call the military districts in the mobilized mode, which will look at
what in fact has happened to those two military districts adjoining Afghanistan.
There had also been some movements involving the military districts adjoining Poland.
And so perhaps from that we can glean some information on how those things function during wartime.
And so that's one study that will be completed shortly.
We have a series of so-called casual papers which deal with Soviet command structure, command changes, and the personalities involved.
The idea here is, again, it's just a business of trying to learn how the Soviets think.
When a commander changes his...
his position, that is, when he's given a new command or moves within the military structure.

We'll go back and get information on his background, where he was born, where he went to school, what kind of military schools did he go through, if we can find it, what were his parents like, and try to get some idea of his background and his training.
And then we'll have a complete review of the military posts that he has been assigned to.
And then we will, if we can find three or four papers that he has authored over the past, say, ten years in military journals or whatever, we'll synopsize those papers.
But when you put that all together, it makes a fascinating package, because here is this guy.
Oh, we recently did one on General Majorov.
And here's this guy sort of laid out before you.
And so you can see his background and his training.
And then when you look at some of his recent writings, which are synopsized, you get some idea of what he's thinking about and what his main concerns are.
And these generally will establish some sort of a pattern.
And so it can be fairly revealing.
So we've published, I guess, three or four studies of that type.
Then a study that is just now being published switches over to the US side.
There are about 10 materials.
which are labeled strategic.
These are metals which are very important to the U.S. military.
Cobalt is one of them.
When you add cobalt to steel, it makes it very hard.
It also increases its magnetic properties and increases its high temperature characteristics, which means that it's very useful for turbine engines and things like that.
It's also very useful in electronic components because of its magnetic enhancement capabilities.
Currently the U.S. gets, depending on what year you look at, anywhere from 75 to 95 percent of its cobalt from Zaire in Central Africa, Southern Africa.
And there's a whole array of these things, tantalum, titanium,
And a lot of people think that oil is the only material where we are at the mercy of other people.
That's wrong.
So we've done a study of looking at what the U.S. might do in the event of a protracted conflict with the Soviets.
There is more and more thinking now that when war comes, that it will not be a nuclear war, that it will be a protracted non-nuclear war.
And so the question is, the U.S. military needs cobalt in sufficient amount to build jet engines and other war materiel.
for the duration of that non-nuclear war.
And if the Soviets could choke off our supply from South Africa, from Southern Africa, I should say, which they could fairly easily do, then where in the name of God do we get the cobalt?
And so the title of the study is Cobalt, Strategic Alternatives for Supply.
And there are
four alternatives for supplying cobalt.
And I won't take time here to delineate all of that.
But what it amounts to is that there is cobalt here in the U.S. and Canada.
There had been cobalt mines here, usually associated with copper mines.
But because of the economics of the situation, it was cheaper to buy it from Zaire and ship it in here.
And so all of our cobalt mines have been shut down, copper mines.
So we need to reopen them.
It turns out that the country that has more cobalt than any other country in the world is Cuba.
Well, in the event of a protracted non-nuclear conflict with the Soviets, are we going to permit them to operate from that base there 90 miles from our shore?
One would think not.
One would hope not.
I'm not espousing an invasion of Cuba, necessarily, on the other hand.
I think to try to pretend that Cuban cobalt does not exist is stupid.

And so one of our recommendations that came out of this report was a suggestion that in our strategic planning that we take into account the fact that Cuba does have those magnificent cobalt reserves and plan accordingly.
Were these reserves being unused at this time?
Oh, yes.
The Soviets are using them.
You bet.
They get 40% of their cobalt from Cuba.
And, of course, using plants that were originally American-built in pre-Castro days.
And then after Castro took over, of course, they were nationalized in an organization called, set up called, Cubanico.
And it's an arm of the Cuban government.
And so they sell, as a matter of fact, that's one of the main elements of the Cuban economy, that and sugar, cobalt and sugar.
And so it...
It's a situation that I think has to be looked at realistically.
I might add that in this report, in this study that we did, we made an estimate of the amount of cobalt that the U.S. would need.
And of course, the U.S. has been stockpiling cobalt and has about 40 million pounds of cobalt in our stockpile currently.
Our estimates indicate that that would be about adequate for the first year of a conflict.
Which would be all right.
I mean, that's great.
That gives us a year or two to do some other things.
The question is, what are the other things you're going to do?
And so I think if we could reopen US mines with more efficient extraction processes, then perhaps be prepared to use the Cuban nickel somewhere or other.
And those strategies are beyond my consideration.
I think all we can do is just simply point out that it's there and it needs to be considered.
And it's amazing.
I've previewed this report before some people in Congress.
They said, Cuba?
Nickel?
Why didn't somebody tell us?
And so this is, I think, another evidence of the kind of fresh thinking that is needed in some of these areas.
There are some other things that we'll be getting into.
Later on, we, of course, here at Texas A&M, we are very strong in the energy field, particularly in natural gas, crude oil production, that sort of thing.
We're also very strong in manufacturing, and manufacturing is undergoing a revolution now with computer-aided systems coming into the scene.
And so we will be doing some of those kinds of studies in the Warsaw Pact and in the USSR.
And then there is one other program that will begin this fall, which will deal with space warfare.
And there is some very clear evidence that the Soviets are moving heavily in this direction with the development of laser and particle beam weapons.
As a matter of fact, they are, according to the evidence, they are probably ahead of the U.S. in that area.

So we've been asked by the US Air Force to make a study of some aspects of the US space program and try to give some recommendations as to what kinds of new technologies need to be developed in order to allow the US to fight and win a war in space.
OK, in closing, is there any other comment that you'd like to make about anything regarding the center
your activities?
Oh, I guess only this.
As I said earlier in the interview, the Center here represents a new effort for Texas A&M.
It represents a new frontier, a new way in which Texas A&M can serve the people of the state of Texas and the people of the United States.
I think, and of course it's a biased view, I think Texas A&M's star is rising.
I think with all due respects to our friends in Austin, I think Texas A&M is becoming the premier institution in the Southwest.
And so I think the center can help contribute to that image and to that structure.
And also,
I would hope the Center can do something else.

You know, there are, of course, many influences on the federal scene, and many of us feel that the influence of the Northeast and the Midwest has exceeded their importance in the general scheme of things.
It seems like when anybody is appointed to a high post in the government, why, he comes from MIT or Caltech or someplace.
And that's not to say that we want Texas or the Southwest to run everything, necessarily.
On the other hand, we think that there needs to be more of a balanced voice in some of these national decision-making processes.
And so I think there is a role here for the center to play.
Of course, here again, I'm not suggesting that we don't have good representation in Congress or anything like that.
we do have.
On the other hand, one cannot lose people like LBJ and Connolly and Olin Teague and Sam Rayburn and so forth without losing a hell of a lot of clout.
You know, our young people are bright and articulate and so forth, but they just don't have the clout that those old boys had.
And so, here again, I think that an outfit like the Center can contribute to that, and
Texas A&M, of course, has as its first mission the education of young people in the state of Texas, and that must remain the first objective for this institution.

But close behind that, I think, has to be a program to serve the people of the state of Texas and, indeed, the people of the United States in other ways, and in ways that a truly intellectual institution can.
And so I think the center can aid in that.
And so we have fairly lofty goals.
But you know how Aggies are.
We'll just swat the hell out of things.
And it doesn't make any difference whether this is a lofty goal or not.
We're going to give it our best shot, and we're going to win.
Thank you very much for this most enlightening interview, Dr. Thomas.
Thank you.
